stream_context.summary: Kaze demos and iterates on a new “Paint Mario” (Mario Paint–inspired) retro sub-area: a dynamic texture you can draw on, a flood-fill tool, a rocket reset, scoring, and an NPC interaction that evaluates your painting and awards a star above a threshold. He also discusses N64 constraints (stack limits, bandwidth, performance), a suspected RTYI crash specific to Parallel RDP/Parallel Launcher, and a speculative discovery of ~1MB of ‘hidden’ N64 memory via a 9th bit per byte.
stream_context.significance_reason: A major interactive minigame loop gets stitched together end-to-end (draw → score → talk to evaluator → star), including key design decisions (no undo) and fixes to score/reset logic.

findings.summary: Kaze shows off-stream progress on a Mario Paint–style “Paint Mario” feature where the player draws directly onto Mario via a dynamically updated texture, with a rocket button to clear/reset the drawing.

The fill tool is implemented as a simple adjacent-pixel flood fill (not ‘intelligent’); Kaze avoids recursion because the N64 stack isn’t large enough and instead uses a manually managed stack of pixels in allocated temporary memory.
Kaze notes texture operations cost bandwidth, but expects this sub-area to still run at 60 FPS; he tests the clear/reset and observes no lag before later hitting a render-thread crash during testing.
He decides against adding an undo feature: the activity is treated as a game challenge rather than an image editor—mistakes reduce score; players only get a reset/clear.
findings.quote: It’s still a game, guys. This is not an image editor. You fuck up, you lose your points.

findings.summary: A scoring/reset bug is identified where resetting/clearing didn’t properly reset score, allowing ‘infinite score’; Kaze concludes the state is stored in too many places and needs refactoring into a separate function/state.

The minigame needs an NPC/trigger that evaluates the drawing and awards a star if the player meets a score threshold; Kaze prototypes this by hooking into an existing ‘ask Mario’ / NPC talk branching function rather than the Wild West NPC system.

Kaze gets the evaluator logic working: if the bottom-left score number is below a threshold (temporarily set to 1,000,000), the NPC grants the star; he then play-tests how incorrect the drawing can be while still passing.

Scoring is inverted from a typical ‘points up’ system: the more correct the drawing, the more the score drops; he discovers a speedrun-viable strategy where only key regions (cap/face/nose/ear/mustache) need to be colored to pass.

Kaze debates which Mario Paint character should evaluate the painting; he favors the Mario Paint ‘robot that saves/loads paintings’ but rejects the ‘Undo Dog’ because it would imply an undo feature that won’t exist.
He switches Mario’s drawing texture to point filtering after chat suggestion and prefers the crisper look for this retro section.

Kaze models a Mario Paint robot-like character in 3D (high poly by N64 standards but acceptable for a small sub-area), aiming for sprite accuracy; he estimates ~300 triangles, less than Mario’s model.

Kaze describes a potentially video-worthy N64 quirk: ~1MB of ‘hidden’ memory by exploiting a 9th bit per byte (coverage/triangle rendering bit) that can be read/written from the CPU with tricks, though access is slower and may only work on every other bit.
He attempted to fix an RTYI crash specific to Parallel RDP/Parallel Launcher but couldn’t reproduce a solution; he says he spoke with Falco and implies the investigation stalled.

Kaze considers post-release ‘asset swapping’ RTYI into an original-IP indie game (since Mario is the only vanilla actor used), but worries about legal optics and says it would require discussing with a lawyer.
Kaze notes remaining work blocking course completion: two ‘Yoshikons’ characters are still missing before the course can be considered done.

Kaze says he consulted Falco while trying to diagnose the Parallel RDP crash, but the issue remained unresolved and Kaze felt ‘gaslit’/stonewalled.
Provides chat feedback (e.g., point filtering suggestion and resource help while Kaze searches for Mario Paint robot assets).

key_stories.title: Building the Paint Mario minigame loop (draw → evaluate → star)
key_stories.summary: Kaze demos a new Mario Paint–inspired activity where players draw on Mario using a dynamic texture, can flood-fill regions, and can reset via a rocket. He then adds a talk-triggered evaluator that checks a score threshold and grants a star, and he play-tests how strict the scoring should be (including speedrun implications).
key_stories.challenge: Create an N64-feasible painting mechanic that feels responsive, has clear rules, and can be judged fairly for a star reward.
key_stories.process: Implemented a non-recursive flood fill using a manually managed pixel stack in temporary memory; added reset/clear; fixed/reset scoring state; hooked an existing ‘ask Mario’ branching talk function to create an evaluator NPC interaction; iterated on threshold and tested ‘how wrong can you be’ edge cases.
key_stories.outcome: The feature works end-to-end with an evaluator that grants a star, a defined ‘no undo’ rule set, and initial balancing insights (minimal-color speedrun strategy is possible).
key_stories.key_quote: It’s still a game, guys. This is not an image editor. You fuck up, you lose your points.

key_stories.title: Choosing an evaluator character without promising undo
key_stories.summary: Kaze looks for a Mario Paint character to act as the judge of the player’s drawing. He considers the Undo Dog but rejects it to avoid implying an undo feature; he instead gravitates toward the Mario Paint save/load robot and starts recreating it for the level.
key_stories.challenge: Find a thematically fitting NPC that communicates ‘evaluation’ without misleading players about available tools (undo).
key_stories.process: Searches for native-resolution assets online; experiments with point filtering for a retro look; recreates the robot as a 3D model with sprite-accurate proportions even if relatively ‘high poly’ for N64.
key_stories.outcome: A direction is set: use the Mario Paint robot (not Undo Dog) as the evaluator, modeled in 3D for the sub-area.
key_stories.key_quote: Undo dog would be great. I’m a little bit scared that the Undo Dog will make people think that they can undo.

key_stories.title: Parallel RDP crash remains unresolved
key_stories.summary: Kaze briefly updates that he tried to fix a crash affecting RTYI in Parallel RDP/Parallel Launcher and couldn’t figure it out, despite talking to Falco. He expresses frustration and a preference to ‘team up’ with other emulators like Project64/RMG instead.
key_stories.challenge: Get RTYI stable on Parallel RDP/Parallel Launcher for players using that rendering path.
key_stories.process: Attempted debugging and sought input from Falco; discussed emulator alternatives publicly on stream.
key_stories.outcome: No fix found during this stream; compatibility remains an open technical risk for release/support.

key_stories.title: Teasing ‘hidden’ N64 memory via a 9th bit
key_stories.summary: Kaze claims the N64 effectively has a ninth bit per byte (used for coverage in rendering) and that it may be possible to read/write it from the CPU, yielding ~1MB of extra storage. He frames it as ‘sounds crazy’ but potentially real and video-worthy, while noting access limitations and performance tradeoffs.
key_stories.challenge: Determine whether this ‘hidden memory’ is practically usable without breaking performance or correctness.
key_stories.process: Explains the conceptual basis (coverage bits), mentions partial access constraints (every other bit), and speculates about extreme methods like writing bits via sub-pixel triangles.
key_stories.outcome: Not implemented in RTYI during the stream, but positioned as a future research/video topic that could influence engine capabilities.
key_stories.key_quote: You’re never going to guess where this megabyte is.

open_questions.topic: Paint Mario scoring function and thresholds
open_questions.context: Kaze uses an inverted score (more correct → score drops) and temporarily awards the star when the bottom-left number is below 1,000,000; he then tests edge cases and notices a minimal-color speedrun path.
questions: What exact metric is used to compare the player’s painted texture to the ‘correct’ Mario (per-pixel difference? weighted regions? palette distance)?
Why choose an inverted ‘lower is better’ score—was it a convenience from existing code, or intentional design?
How will you set the final threshold to balance casual play vs. challenge, and will you add difficulty variants (e.g., strict mode)?
Will you address the speedrun strategy (only paint key regions) or embrace it as emergent gameplay?

open_questions.context: He plans an evaluator character (likely the Mario Paint save/load robot) that the player talks to in order to receive a judgment and potentially a star.
questions: How will the evaluator communicate what went wrong (generic ‘bad’ vs. specific feedback like ‘mustache missing’)?
Will the evaluator be placed in a visible location or hidden (ceiling idea) and why?
What animation/voice/SFX will sell the Mario Paint vibe without needing exact asset rips?

open_questions.context: Kaze explicitly refuses undo to keep it a game with stakes; he worries that using ‘Undo Dog’ would mislead players.
questions: Was there internal/team debate about adding undo (even limited undo), and what made you draw the line?
How will tutorials/UI messaging prevent frustration while preserving consequences?
Will resets have a cost (time, score penalty, attempts) to maintain tension?

open_questions.topic: Flood fill algorithm under N64 constraints
open_questions.context: He uses a manual stack in temporary memory to avoid recursion/stack overflow; fill expands over adjacent pixels of the same color.
questions: How large can a fill operation get before it risks frame drops, and what safeguards exist (step budget per frame, chunking)?
Where exactly is the temporary ‘stack’ allocated (RAM pool, segmented memory, ROM-reserved area), and what tradeoffs did that require?
Did you consider scanline flood fill or other algorithms, and why was the simple approach ‘cheap enough’?

open_questions.context: Kaze says RTYI crashes in Parallel and he and Falco couldn’t figure it out.
questions: What are the symptoms (when/where does it crash, deterministic vs. random, which level/feature triggers it)?
Is it likely a rendering-thread issue, undefined behavior in microcode/display lists, or emulator bug?
What’s the support plan for release—document ‘known incompatible emulators’, provide patches, or pursue a fix with emulator devs?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentions two characters for ‘Yoshikons’ are missing before the course is done.
questions: What are the Yoshikons characters (NPCs? enemies? collectibles), and what role do they play in Course 15?
Who is responsible for creating them (modeling/animation/behavior), and what’s the current bottleneck?
Are they required for core progression or optional polish?

open_questions.context: Kaze claims ~1MB of usable ‘hidden’ memory by leveraging a ninth bit per byte, usually for coverage; access is slower and may be partial (every other bit).
questions: Have you proven read/write correctness on real hardware, or only in emulation?
What practical use-case in RTYI would justify slower access (save data? caching? decompression buffers? telemetry/debug)?
What are the risks (compatibility across N64 revisions, RDRAM behavior, cache interactions)?

open_questions.topic: Asset-swap into original IP and legal strategy
open_questions.context: Kaze floats converting RTYI into an original-IP indie game by swapping Mario and other recognizable assets, but worries about legal implications and says a lawyer would be needed.
questions: How far along is this idea (just hypothetical, or are you designing RTYI systems to be ‘IP-swappable’)?
What elements would remain identical (physics, level layouts, mechanics) vs. what would need redesign to feel like its own game?
What legal guidance are you seeking (copyright, derivative work concerns, marketing language, release timing)?
